23372008.review:
The Way wears it's Another World inspiration on it's sleeve, but it draws heavily from a dozen "dead" classic genres. At times it bears a striking resemblance to LucasArts classic adventures, while at others it skews heavily toward Prince of Persia (the original, not the 3D remake).

The story is OUTSTANDING. Rich, emotional, well-told... as an adventure game, it's up there with the greats; and the fantastic quality of the art and music really help drive it home.

Where The Way stumbles however, is in it's sudden precipitous difficulty spikes and unexpected changes in gameplay type. For example, the first act of the game is largely adventure-oriented, almost like a spiritual successor to Sword & Sworcery EP... then suddenly you are thrust into a Prince of Persia/Another World-style running and leaping chase sequence. 

Compounding the frustration is the awkward mouse-based aiming mechanic. Instead of using a "radial" aim, you have full mouse movement and your character will shoot at the cursor. This becomes a problem in later stages as your cursor is bound to the window even as your character moves on screen, which unexpectedly changes your line of sight.

There's even a rock-dodging racing segment reminiscent of Full Throttle... unfortunately it's marred by a substandard implementation: although there are 3 "lanes", the game doesn't lock you to those lanes, leading to your character doing a LOT of unexpected crashing as you just don't have the precision needed to clear the rocks on a pixel-precise basis.

The final stages are especially infuriating, as the game suddenly introduces bullet-hell gameplay on top the Prince of Persia platforming that also requires precision shooting with the aforementioned awkward mouse controls. Unfortunately, this also means you almost certainly won't be able to pass the late game using a Steam Controller... and a standard gamepad is out of the question.

These are problems that could be easily fixed with some relatively minor tweaks. If the developers evened out the difficulty and polished up some of the controls/mechanics, The Way could be a classic for the ages. As it stands, it's rough around the edges, and it's occassionally an equally rough play... but even so, the puzzles are smart, the story is wonderful, and the art, music, and hidden sci-fi and gaming references make this a title I still recommend.

Just go in knowing what you're in for, and accept that you're going to encounter some really punishing rough patches. If you can get past those, The Way is a very rewarding, satisfying game.

If the dev could fix the latter problem and simply add more checkpoints this would be really good.

Overall? It's ok, but the latter issues make playing through what should otherwise be an amazing experience into an annoying slog and chore. If Dev fixes at least one of these issues (the latter being the easiest) then I will recommend.

23306429.review:
The Way é um jogo de Puzzle Platform com um pouquinho de ação.

A ação do jogo é pouquissima, pelo menos no começo do jogo, você consegue uma Laser Gun que se parece mais com um Taser do que com uma Laser Gun mesmo. Esta Laser Gun é capaz de destruir inimigos mecanicos e matar inimigos pequenos, mas inimigos medios apenas são atordoados. Eu ainda não encontrei inimigos grandes, mas provavelmente a Laser Gun ou vai atordoar ou fazer nada.

VEI, O PUZZLE DESTE JOGO É FANTASTICO.
Primeiramente vou dizer que é dificil pra caralho, são muitos detalhes que você tem que prestar atenção e, maravilhosamente, anotar cada informação. O melhor do Puzzle deste jogo é que ele não é automatico, nem tem "mini-mapa" ou "track" para fazer o Puzzle por você.

Vou dar exemplo do primeiro mapa, provavelmente todo mundo já viu em Gameplay para saber como funciona o jogo, mas não vou dar Spoilers então podem ficar tranquilos... PELOS TRAILERS seu objetivo é reviver sua mulher que morreu de alguma forma, e só tem um unico geito para trazer ela de volta, não sabemos o que é, não sabemos como vamos fazer, MAS.... Precisamos ir para outro planeta, e pra isso precisamos de uma nave, então basicamente o primeiro mapa é arranjar uma nave para ir pro outro planeta.

PORRA, É MUITO LINDO, pra você arranjar a nave, você precisa fazer 4 coisas... Eu posso dizer o que são né? Não é Spoiler, Spoiler é dizer como resolver o Puzzle... Então, pra fazer a nave funcionar, você precisa do corpo de sua mulher, de energia, de liberação para voar e liberação do hangar para sair. Pra você fazer cada uma dessas coisas, você precisa fazer alguma outra coisa antes.

VOCÊ precisa anotar todas as informações que você receber durante o jogo, porque seu personagem não faz nada automatico, eu adorei tanto isso no jogo T.T se o jogo mostra um cogico, você tem que anotar porque quando você chegar no lugar de por o codigo, o personagem não vai por automaticamente, VOCÊ tem que por... E os cogidos são grandes e complicados.

Dicas sobre o Puzzle ficam espalhados no mapa como anotações e desenhos, se você não ler tudo, você não vai saber de nada e por isso não vai poder completar o jogo.

Nossa, nem preciso falar do Pixel Art deste jogo, é lindo pra caralho.

23299176.review: If you liked Another World and/ord Flashback, check this game out.  Good storyline and excellent puzzles.  Very engaging game!

23296839.review:
The Way is an Another World/Flashback-esque adventure, platform, puzzle game. Overall, it tries to capture the look and feel of these old classic games, and mostly captures it. I really applaud the developers on their effort especially considering this is an indie title designed by a couple of people.

However, some puzzles and action pieces of the game are (as of the current version) really awful. The game presents itself as a very atmospheric adventure game with some puzzle elements, but in some cases it turnes into a Nintento hard, frustrating memorization game with extremely precise hit detection that tries to tire you down into rage quitting it. 

Pros:
 - Extremely good visuals and on par soundtrack.
 - Captivating environments that goes hand in hand with the story.
 - Kind of classic but well-executed storyline.
 - Some level of drama that makes you care for the characters.

Cons:
 - Some of the most infuriating puzzle and platforming sequences I've seen for some number of years.
 - From time to time you forget that you are playing a story-driven adventure game but a game with silly frustrating puzzles.
 - In some cases, horrible pixel precise hit detection.
 - Too few cut scenes that makes you want more of the story.

In short, I recommend the game but really you have to be a patient player to overcome some of the puzzles and platforming elements. On the other hand, if a new player wants to recapture the adventure puzzle games of early 90's with all its bizzare and frustrating puzzles, look no further than "The Way"

P.S. to developers: I think "The Way" has been a very poor choice of name since it is so common of a game name element, when searching for a content for the game on the Internet, it mixes up with a ton of other games.

23277639.review:
[h1][i]What wouldn't one do for saving his loved one?[/i][/h1]

I love this puzzle platformer, despite it being mildly frustrating due to the puzzle difficulty.

[b][u]Shorter version of the review[/u][/b]
This is a slow-paced puzzle platformer, personally i felt like crying at times due to the difficulty of the puzzles (I am not a big puzzle enthusiast, perhaps others might find these puzzles easier)
You won't run and gun everything you see, instead, you will need time to think through and to make a plan, and you need to pay attention to the hidden clues throughout the game.
While you do all of these, you will be accompanied by great viusals and atmosphere (Oh trust me, pixels or not, the visuals are atonishing).
I am not sure about the playtime, i would say around 14 hours, i had to play most of the time offline due to some local issues (not game-related).

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]
The beginning, despite it being a bit sad, it was still very beautiful artistically speaking, you had a pretty solid idea of what happened and what to do, so you won't be 'out of it'.
There's no real tutorial which makes things more interesting, thus being said, you have small hints everywhere you go.
You might die few times until you figure out how to avoid enemies, learn their pathways, but you shouldn't try to agitate yourself much yet.
What i loved overall from the gameplay is that you never got the chance to even get bored, the atmosphere is perfect, and there's always a little something to keep you entertained.

The puzzles are a bit hard, but then again, you are not being rushed so you can take as much time as you need to understand what the deal is with each of the puzzles, if something keeps not working then try to do thing differently.
Also, i found the controls to be a bit clunky sometimes, but due to the nature of the game (being slow-paced, and not being forced to run and do many things as quickly as possible), they weren't very annoying.
I'd like to finish up with this section as i am afraid i might give any unintentional spoilers, or just be too "shady" on certain aspects and leave everyone in the dark.

[b][u]Atmosphere and Music[/u][/b]
Atmosphere in this game is purely amazing, all the things that fall into this category match themselves and work perfectly together.
The music scores in the game are delicate and gentle, they pleased because they were so discrete that sometimes when you focus too much you can't even hear the music anymore. 

For me, the first game that popped up in my mind with a similar atmosphere was 'The Silent Age'.

[b][u]Small message for the devs[/u][/b]
This quick small chapter i will write as a personal message to the visual artists.
Thank you! You did an amazing job, the way lighting and shadows were applied to every object in the game was purely brilliant, i found myself many times just stopping from actually playing, just to enjoy the beautiful view.


[h1]This small reading journey ends here, i expressed everything i felt i need to.[/h1]

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Perfect atmosphere and music
[*]Beautiful story that most of you might bond with
[*]Active developers that do care about bugs and really work on them
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]The checkpoints where the game saves your progress aren't perfect
[*]Controls can be a little clunky
[*]You can't use both gamepad/mouse at the same time (If you want to do a part of the game with the mouse, you have to switch that in the settings)
[/list]

My rating for it would be a solid 80/100, and i do encourage you to try this one if you enjoy puzzles, beautiful atmosphere, and simple but powerful stories.

23277336.review:
[h1] У меня появилась новая любимая игра! [/h1]

[b] Вас ждут:[/b]
[list]
    [*] [i] Интересная история.[/i] Да, сама история может показаться несколько банальной и предсказуемой, но следить за событиями, тем не менее, очень интересно. Отдельно хочется отметить режиссерскую работу - здесь продумана каждая сцена, причем это относится не только к сюжетным вставкам, но и к геймлею.
    [*] [i] Логичные головоломки.[/i] Для меня это большой плюс.  Загадки, кстати, не очень сложные, хотя иногда и заставляют поломать голову.
    [*] [i] Великолепная пиксельная графика.[/i] Персонажи, локации, сюжетные вставки - все прекрасно нарисовано и радует глаз. 
    [*] [i] Захватывающий и разнообразный геймлей.[/i] По ходу игры возможности главного героя постоянно меняются и не успевают надоесть.
[/list]

Из недостатков могу отметить немного кривой перевод (может помешать пройти в одном месте, в самом начале, в остальном особо не критично), в одном месте криво настроенная система чекпоинтов (вроде как уже пофиксили, но я то место не перепроходил) и... все. Больше недостатков у этой игры я не нашел.

В целом - это отличная приключенческая игра в научно-фантастическом стиле. Если будет продолжение (пусть не прямое, а косвенное, об этом намекают после титров), не задумываясь куплю.

TLDR; Aweseom game with about 10 hours of gameplay and little replayability. Still worth it IMO.

This game delivered everything that I hoped it would: A retro nostalgia, a moving story line, with some humour and pop culture references on the side.

The game took me 9.7hours to finish. Many of the puzzels were just at the right level of difficulty, though some were so difficult I had to look up what the puzzle *was* before I could even attempt a solution.

Some complained about the two game squences that were not at all platformers, and whilst these sequences were a bit crap, they were not hard, and didn't get in the way of my enjoyment of the game.

I may replay this just for the achievements, though given that most of the fun is in the story line, and in solving the puzzles, I'm not sure how fun this is going to be.

23245492.review:
A gorgeous platforming adventure in the vein of the legendary "Another World", "Flashback" and "Heart of Darkness" by Éric Chahi. This game has it all: Exciting story, gorgeous pixel art, very responsive controls, breathtaking soundtrack and overall great game mechanics.

HOWEVER: I still don't get how developers think that ANY gamer out there really really wants mini puzzles à la "Pipe Dream" (a.k.a. the "Bioshock" hacking game), "Simon Says" or sliding tile puzzles. We are wandering through undiscovered alien ruins and THAT'S how they protect their ancient secrets? By mini puzzles a little kid can solve? Yeah right... aaaand there goes the suspension of disbelief.

That's my only gripe with the game though. If you don't care about stuff like that: Go ahead and buy the thing. (It's well worth the asking price anyway!) If you're a fan of the aforementioned classic platformers, this is an absolute MUST-HAVE anyway.

23242115.review:
The Way is a puzzle platformer whose story deals with the themes of love and loss, and perhaps the resistance to loss some people display in its wake. Tom, the main character, is a recent widower who travels to an alien world in order to revive his wife. 

The story is somwhat minimalistic in its telling. Quite a lot of the details are left unsaid, but what is unshared isn't really important. It's a story about what is happening now, not what has already happened.
The puzzles are well crafted, with the hints needed to solve them usually nearby. You just have to keep your eyes open.
The music is atmospheric and accompanies the game well.
The sprite art is gorgeous.

That said, it is not without its flaws, though I feel they are thankfully few.
Platforming is not the games strongpoint, with a few very demanding and unforgiving segments. I did play on keyboard though, so perhaps the digital nature of the keys hampered my ability to be more precise in my movements.
The story raises one or two points that go unresolved. This isn't a huge deal, it just feels a bit odd.

Another thing I should mention is that the developers have been very attentive to feedback, adding improvements to the game based on community criticism. Originally there was no auto-run option, for example.

23241345.review: The controls are a little stiff, but that shouldn't stop you from playing this atmospheric exploration puzzle/platformer. This lead to frustration o'plenty. Good news is that this only happened a couple of times, but it was bad enough to make me quit for awhile. If you like this genre of game, it is definitely worth playing.

23205149.review:
Well, this is definitely the most polarizing game I've played in a while. I backed this game, but later forgot about it, so when I started playing I had absolutely no recollection of the plot, what little I might have known. That was a good thing: this game has probably the BEST beginning half-hour I've seen since the first half of Wall-E. No words, no dialogue, just the acts and thoughts of the main character, and they tell you everything that you need to know in order to empathise with him. This feeling of discovery actually lasts for quite a while, since even after getting to the alien planet I was amazed by everything that I came into contact with, like a genuine explorer of a new world... that is, until I left the first part of the game, which I call "Story World", and I arrived at "Puzzle World".

--------------------------------- SPOILER ALERT --------------------------------

From this moment on, the plot just sits patiently in a corner until you're done with the puzzles, then tells you a little bit of how the story goes on, then sits again to let you jump, climb, teleport and move green pieces all around. This is when the game started to lose me, but I pressed on, mainly because the story was interesting, but also because the puzzles were, at times, really damn ingenious. There are some here and there where I just had to roll my eyes in disbelief (Sliding puzzles? Really?), but they were really interesting to crack for the most part.

Then we arrive at the third part of the game, "Action World", where high precision jumps are the norm and hundreds of deaths are the punishment for failure. This is where the writers' inspiration seems to have run out: the last thing I expected to see in a heavily dramatic, plot-driven game such as this one is a stage where you have to fight the Purple Tentacle from Maniac Mansion and the zombie pirate LeChuck. Yes, I know, "it's an hommage", right? Well, for me, an hommage is a picture in the background, a statue on the floor, or a few notes of a recognisable tune, not modelling an action level of your dramatic game with characters from other games, brilliant and influential as they might be. And having a bullet hell stage as the final boss, in a game with a plot that doesn't really need any kind of "final boss", is just lazy writing to me.

Finally, at the end of the story it is revealed that the "immortality solution" which the main character has been searching all his life is just storing a person's mind in a computer, something which I'm pretty sure that his own society already had the ability to do. I mean, they have perfected interstellar travel and full-body stasis chambers, yet they can't make a copy of the neuronal network of a person? It just doesn't make sense. And the ending? A few still images transitioning from one to another. That's it. No emotion at all. Oh, and the worst part: a cliffhanger at the end. Just perfect.

--------------------------------- SPOILER  END ---------------------------------

All in all, it saddens me that a game with such a brilliant beginning (again, one of the best written and executed I've ever seen) gradually devolved into an uninspired succession of puzzles and action sequences, some even completely outside the context of the story. Even so, I recommend everyone to play this game, even if it's just for the parts where the plot comes back with new evolution for our main character and the inhabitants of the world he's exploring. Oh, and for the fantastic, submersive and delightful soundtrack, arguably the best character of the game.

23186801.review:
Interesting idea and a beautiful artstyle, but done less well. Spoiler Free review, btw..

Anyone who has ever played Flashback or Another World will instantly think of these two games, and to some extent this game emulates the cinematic platformer style from those games. It doesn't do it very well, sadly.

I will say, that the idea behind the abilities you have in the game is good, even if it often fails to be as good as it could be.

It is hard to go too much into detail without spoiling the game, so I will just go over the things that eventually made me not want to play any more (in ascending order of annoyance):


Autosave:

95% of the time the autosave kicks correctly in just before dangerous places, where you most likely will die. The last 5% of the time it saves somewhere far far away from what you are doing beacuse it was triggered by you passing a point it wants to save at and all the danger save spots, which are often one-time save spots, are gone. 


Puzzle objective:

Often you need to do something very specific to get past an obstacle. In the player's mind there might be myriad of different ways to bypass the problem you are faced with, but since this is a linear game, you need to figure out what the developer wants you to do and that is sometimes very convoluted. Not a big problem, but can be a bit frustrating.


Puzzles breaking immersion:

It starts out with a story that moves you through interesting puzzles that are a natural part of the world (like security you have to get past when trespassing) and then quickly devolves into puzzles that just feel forced into the setting without it making any sense for the puzzle to be there. It detracts from the story and the world and makes it feel much less like a game and more like a flimsy frame for the puzzles.


Puzzle feedback:

Some puzzles rely heavily on you understanding what you are doing and how you are interacting with the them. Yet the game often forgets that what is immediately obvious once you figure it out is frustratingly hard to understand if you don't get any feedback from the game when you try the logical solution and something makes it fail.


Puzzle design:

Some puzzles have you doing things in one area while the info you need or the reaction to your actions is somewhere far away on the other side of a horde of things that can kill you or just takes a lot of time to get past (falls/enemies/slow climbing/traps/etc.). Some puzzles have you do a lot of things that require that you study an area you can only see in short glimpses unless you (like me) take screenshots. It makes interesting puzzles, that could be fun into colossal time wasters which are frustrating to no end. One puzzle I solved by going through all permutations of possible solutions simply because it would take me more time to go check on the outcome of my actions than just laboriously go through all possible solutions.


Platformer parts:

This is what finally broke the camel's back for me. There are soooo many parts where you have to traverse long insta-death platformer parts with spikes and falls and things like it. Could be a nice part of the game, but the controls are very imprecise and the physics of the game are strange (Ex: while sliding down an incline you cannot change your speed when you are touching the incline, but you can stop all horisontal movement or speed it up a bit if you jump and use the sideways movement buttons while in the air. It makes no sense). Tiny spikes about 30 cm below you -- can't step down slowly and just walk slowly through them (you can move through them if you stand next to them), you have to jump high up into the air and try to land in that one tiny spot where your character has about 2-3 pixels leeway on both sides or you die.


Conclusion:

I wanted to like this game. No, I wanted to love it. It just has too many frustrating parts.

23177679.review:
This is one of my favourite games I have played this year. The art, world, atmosphere, puzzles and action are sublime. The graphics, music and story come together perfectly to create a hauntingly beautiful world to explore and understand.  Some of the puzzles are fiendishly difficult at first, and you will benefit from a pen and paper for a lot of them. However, once the solution is found it seems like the answer was staring you in the face all along....a hallmark of good puzzle design!

As a spiritual successor to Flashback and similar games from a classic era, parts of the game are brutally punishing and it can sometimes feel like trial and error as you explore new areas. However, I felt that the game is much fairer than any of the games it is influenced by. Again, the feeling of satisifaction when you overcome a particularly tricky action sequence is worth the price of admission.

Finally, the developer is very active on the Steam Discussion boards and is very responsive to feedback from players, such as adding more autosave points, helping players solve puzzles, and updating as to future patch plans.

This game is clearly a labour of love and I look forward to seeing what the developer comes up with next.

23175549.review: This Game  is a real love letter to the slower paced, more meticulous classic platformers that really started to catch on in the early to mid '90s. Prince of Persia, Out of this World/Another World, Flashback, Blackthorn etc. This game might be a tad more forgiving by ditching opressive time limits, and punishing respawn points, but it more than makes up for it a at times, tedious yet fun 2D challenge. One misstep can see you plummet to your doom, accompanied by a sickening crunch. Rush into a dark room too fast and you will pay the price! There are fun puzzels, neat and modern shooting mechanics (where bullets and poor aim, have consequence), and of course platforming, along with well paced metroidvania style exploration. Graphics are just fine and charming, reminiscent and artfully faithful to the 16-bit era. The music is very moody and well composed. The writing drives the story forward in a minimalistic, yet effectively cryptic tone. I would highly recommend this to the old school fans of the consol era and those who appreciate a challenge in the anyone interested in 2D platfroming genres with science fiction setting. There's even quite a few easter eggs and nods to the genre just for those who know what to look for. ;) Highly recommended!

23174154.review:
[b]TL, DR[/b]: 3/5. You will be frustrated, but you should give it a try.

There are many disappointing aspects about [i]The Way[/i]. Controls are not good at all (keyboard movement controls aren't good for platforming and my XBox One controller didn't work for shooting at all even after rebinding the fire button), the save points are badly placed (forcing you to replay large swaths of a level after making one wrong control input at the end of a long sequence), and there are some questionable mechanical decisions (there is a final boss fight which introduces completely new mechanics for some reason). There is a nonsensical "choose an ending" decision at the end of the game, but I cannot imagine the main character thinking there was any option other than the one he had been working toward for the entire game. Some puzzle design is obtuse (ie. you may not even know that there is a puzzle you are supposed to be solving until you die multiple times).

For a game which calls itself a platformer, the platforming movement feels floaty and awkard. There are moments where the game requires very precise control, but it can be very difficult to translate your intended movement into actual movement in the game.

For a game which invokes Another World in its marketing, the character sprite animation is not as detailed as it probably should be. Three frames of jump animation for the main player character feels a little lame.

While this game was very frustrating at times, I'm glad I played it. The background art is beautiful and creative. The music is exceptional. Even the story, as basic as it is, manages to create some emotion which helps align the player with the main character. I hope that the developers have the opportunity to create another game in the future which can avoid the issues present here.

23163221.review:
I have waited two years for this game to come out. I love cinematic platformers and the moment I saw this game on Kickstarter I knew that it had great potential to be one of the best in its genre.

The Way is inspired by games such as Another World and Flashback, and if you have any familiarity with those games then it's hard not to see where the developers took their inspirations from.

The storyline, while incredibly simple, nonetheless manages to tug hard at the heartstrings. Tom is extremely obsessed with bringing his wife back, no matter the cost, and it's hard not to root for him when you see what he has to go through. The universe in general is really a very fascinating place, and I would definitely love to see more games taking place inside it. 

While the character animations aren't nearly as complex as the ones featured in its inspirations, The Way still offers a very appealing visual style. The backgrounds are crisp and detailed, and you really get a sense of visiting another world. 

This is an old-school experience, one that offers very little hand holding. The only real tutorials occur at the beginning of the game and offer the most basic movement controls. After that, you're on your own to figure everything else out. The first level alone feels like something that would appear in the mid-to-late portion of other games, and it only gets trickier and more intense from there.

The Way is one of the most varied games I've played in recent memory. While it is definitely a platformer, it also utilizes aspects of stealth, puzzle, action, and even shooters during the course of the 10 hour adventure. From solving complex puzzles, to sneaking past robots, the game covers a wide ground of concepts and ideas, and always makes sure to keep things fresh throughout the 10 hour adventure.

The thing that really brings this game together is its incredible soundtrack, which is easily my favorite so far this year. The music has a mystical, alien quality, relying heavily on bizarre synthesizer effects, droning melodies, and haunting production. I would definitely love to listen to this outside of the game, something I can say for very few soundtracks. 

The Way evokes a real sense of awe and wonder, something that seems to be missing from today's market of fast-paced action and over-marketed games. It represents much that was good about gaming in the early 1990s while making sure to keep the experience moving along for 2016 audiences. In short, it's everything the developers promised it would be.

It's like they're mostly lifted from other platformers with just small mechanics tweaked here and there, often making things much worse. Playing this game feels like I'm being punished for not knowing in advance how the developer's thought process on puzzle design works.

Lovely pixel-art characters
Beautiful backgrounds
Original bestiary

Sound :
--------
Immersing ambient music which always reflect the level's atmosphere without boring the player.

23146388.review:
As someone who hadn't played the original games like Another World or similar, I thought this game was fun and worth the price. The pixel art and creative level designs are immersive and fun to explore. I liked the puzzles the most, and the platforming is fun, but it would better if the controls were tighter (it's more on the Prince of Persia side of the spectrum than the Super Meat Boy side).

My biggest complaint is that the gameplay is punctuated by (sometimes very) frustrating parts where there is significant "respawn" time, ie time it takes to just get to where the puzzle/platform is. This game would be a lot more enjoyable if the saves were more frequent. Most saves in this game only fire after certain events, not on your location. For example in a large zone ([spoiler]bounty hunter area[/spoiler]), my save was in the bottom right corner of the map, but the current task was a difficult platform sequence in the far upper left. It took about 5 minutes to just get back, and then die, repeatedly, trying to navigate a series of 1-block sized platforms. This ended up taking about 40 min of running/climbing and probably 2 minutes of working on the platforms. This comes up often and is a drag. I hope that this is a mechanic the devs fix in a future patch.

I beat the game and the criticisms of the (current) top reviewer don't seem fair to me. I thought the land cruiser and bullet-hell parts were fun. A bullet-hell sequence where you beat it after a few deaths wouldn't be much of a bullet-hell ([spoiler] as the final boss no less![/spoiler]). I haven't played the older games so I can't speak to if they're too similar. I do agree with the complaint about the saves, but don't think that negates the overall enjoyable qualities of the game: artwork, world, and fun+challenging puzzles/platforming.

23143874.review:
I _want_ to love this game. No, I don’t necessarily have to _love_ it. But I do wish that I could at least enjoy playing it.

I like “The Way”, I really do. The game’s presentation is outstanding and the sad story is captivating enough to make me wanna see how it resolves. A few of the puzzles are interesting and well thought out, and almost every background view would make for an incredibly beautiful painting.

Sadly, I can’t find the motivation or willpower to continue playing... Not after having died and respawned at _the same friggin’_ spot way more times than I should have to put up with. I remember doing this way back in the 90’s as well, playing “Flashback” over and over again, and also “Another World/Out of This World”. Those two games are the main reason why I even backed “The Way” on Kickstarter. But that was then and now is now. As much as I still do love “Flashback” (hey just look at my avatar – which I’ve been using since the beginning of teh Interwebz) and all of its occasionally frustrating gameplay elements, I just can’t help feeling even more frustrated as I experience the same, no I’d even say _worse_ penalty, playing “The Way”.

It’s not just about lacking the time and patience to do the same part over and _over_ again, which wasn’t that big of a deal when I was a 12-year-old. But I also can’t help but feel that this game somehow deserves more than this, that it should be smarter than penalizing the player like this. It shouldn’t be so much about going back and forth between dying and respawning at a painstakingly old and ill-placed checkpoint. “Platforming” is fun, for sure, and “The Way” does have its moments when it comes to both running-and-jumping as well as the puzzle solving – which _should_ be one of the game’s strongest points. But when I find myself constantly running into poor design choices, leaving me frustrated and annoyed, that’s when I can’t help but think “Don’t I actually have better things to do and more entertaining gaming experiences than this that I could turn to?”

--
Edit: And I get what many of you are probably thinking right now, that “it’s all about patience”. But no, not it’s not. Not in this case. There’s a huge difference between carefully figuring out how to find that secret door which will let you continue, and simply bashing your head against the wall until it breaks. “The Way” _should_ be more about the first option, but too often do I find myself forced to go with the second one.

It’s like that one point in “Another World/Out of this World” where you need to press a bunch of buttons in a certain order before time runs out and you die. There’s no logic to this puzzle – you simply keep pressing the buttons until a new set of buttons appear, and try to memorize which button did what so that you’ll become faster on your next try. Although the puzzle fits thematically, seeing as how the game’s protagonist has never seen these type of controls before and thus have no choice but to press buttons at random, it’s not exactly a good one. But since you at least get a checkpoint right before it happens, and also once you’ve finished, it still feels ok. Especially since there aren’t _that_ many buttons which needs to be pressed before the player is allowed to continue playing. Unfortunately, the checkpoints are sparse here in “The Way” and the random elements aren’t that quickly transcended as this particular puzzle which I just described.

And that’s the difference between good and poor game design: throwing things at the player that doesn’t require logical thinking or good reflexes, but rather simply feels like a hindrance in order to squeeze out more play-time by throwing something random at you. Kind of like when developers choose to allow the AI to cheat, because it’s easier than programming it to be clever and outsmart you.
--

Although I probably only have another 4 hours left of this game before I finish it, I’ve decided to wait for a “let’s play” series on YouTube instead. I simply cannot watch my character die and respawn another time, or try and solve yet another vague puzzle.

I’m sorry to leave the game like this, but most of all - I’m sad and a bit disappointed at how it all turned out.

23140546.review:
I'm one of the kickstarters backer's of "The Way". Two years ago, in 2014, I didn't know exactly what to expect of it, besides being a homage to Another World, Flashback and Heart of Darkness. Now, two years later, I can say it's more of a homage, it's truly a game that evolves on the spirit and gameplay of those games. It has action and puzzles, but as the game progress, the puzzles are less about action and speed, and more about understanding and planning what to do next. Also, it's a very heartwarming story right from the title screen, showing how far the main character is willing to go. While the game has some textual narrative, most of the storytelling is done with visual clues, showing the passage of time and adding weight to the emotional aspect of the storytelling.

From the gameplay aspect, the action sequences are well done, when a sequence starts, the player has little time to figure it out what to do, and usually just one chance to do it right. Any failure is instakill, but the game has a good amount of checkpoints for a less punishing gameplay, even if they aren't always where you wish they were. The tools the player has at his disposal changes as the game progresses, forcing the player to take a different approach in the action sequences. Thus, the game is always fresh, never getting too old, never getting too easy, never failing to punish a bad decision and always being an emotional journey. For me, it's a 10 out of 10 for anyone who loves oldschool platform titles.

Pour mon avis détaillé en français:

The Way is not a bad game. It is not a very good game too.
In fact, it has good ideas, good story, gorgeous graphics ... but plenty of flaws which ruin the fun.

One of the biggest flaw of the game is the controls, very rigid, very approximate ; and the biggest flaw is the fact that the game features plateform, shooting, and even actual bullet hell sequences, with its controls which are totally unsuitable for such stages. Result : there is far, far, more frustration than fun.

In other flaws, I find that the level-design brings too much (really too much!) useless goings and comings, like to artificially expand the lifetime ; lots of puzzles are dull (but some are excellent!) and too many are poorly directed ; lots of moment are boring (when you have to cross a large wall, moving slowly from ladders to ladders and patiently waiting for sandfalls to stop... or repetitive sequences against the robots... :/).

The good points of the game: its story ! The gorgeous graphics and ambiance. And some really good puzzles.

So, overall, is it a good game ? Maybe ; if you are curious AND lenient.
Do I recommand it ? No ; not for anybody, only if you know what to excpect, and you think it worth its price.

23120114.review:
The Way is a 2D platformer that plays like a lovechild of Another World and The Dig – you explore an alien planet filled with remnants of long-gone civilization, discover underground complexes, avoid predators and befriend the natives.

PROS:
- Very atmospheric. Crisp, stylized graphics, haunting soundtrack and rich animation perfectly capture the alien world.
- Overall focus on puzzles instead of combat. There is relatively little gunplay in the game, and most enemies and obstacles are overcome by indirect means.
- Some excellent environmental puzzles that make you feel clever when you finally figure them out.
- Good length. At about 9-10 hours, the games feels appropriately substantial but does not overstay its welcome.

CONS:
- The story works well for the most part, but the relationship between protagonist and his wife could use some fleshing out (and the wife character in general – she doesn’t have a single line of dialogue and doesn’t even have a name so it’s a bit hard to care for her).
- Some of the action sequences can be frustrating.

23117518.review:
Alrighty, I had to give this review an entire re-write. At first I gave the game a very borderline "not recommended" review. There were some things about the game design that myself (and apparently some others) really didn't like, and which were preventing me from enjoying the game. Then within about 48 hours the developers released a patch which blew those problems away. I was really wanting to recommend this game so I'm glad that now I can. And I appreciate the devs tweaking the game based on customer feedback. They didn't have to. The problems and confusion some people have had with the game weren't experienced by everyone. The game was released just as advertised and it's not the devs' problem if it's not some people's cup of tea. But I really think the changes they've been making improve the game for everyone.

[i]The Way[/i] is a platformer and a puzzler and an adventure. It's got a lot of the gameplay from [i]Flashback[/i] and [i]Another World[/i]. You'll need to do a lot of platforming with some timing and speed challenges included. It's got a fair amount of enemies thrown in, but it never goes full action game. There are also static puzzles of a wide variety like arranging things in the right sequence etc. And a few arcadey sections. It's the arcadey sections which put me off the game on my first attempt. The final one (a bullet hell sequence) proving an insurmountable barrier to beating the game. There was nothing remotely similar to that kind of gameplay in the rest of the game and it felt unfair for the final obstacle of the game to be an abrupt switch to a different genre. The devs ended up making it a lot easier so I've since beaten the game. It's still a bit of an odd choice for the final challenge though. I was expecting something a bit more "Commander Keen" where you have to frantically jump around a level triggering things that zap a boss monster.

I found a few sections of the game a little frustrating but nothing I wasn't willing to come back to. Most of the time this was due to constantly dying in one section, but respawning a fair distance away from that section and having to work my way back to it many times over. The devs have taken peoples' feedback about these areas and I believe they've moved auto save points closer to all the parts that were frustrating me. These parts still provide a challenge and it still feels good to beat them but now it's not so tedious. Sometimes I would even die on purpose just to see if there was a unique death animation for that hazard :)

The level design is mostly really good. Some of the puzzles interact with each other and are multi-function with different "solutions" depending on what you need to do next. There are a few times when you can't progress until you figure out the trick to interacting with that particular part of the level.

The story is pretty good. The developer says one of the influences was the Lucasart point and click adventure [i]The Dig[/i]. I can see the influence. [i]The Dig[/i] was a concept created by Stephen Spielberg with writing by Orson Scott Card though so don't expect anything on quite that level. It's still impressive for three dudes. It's a bit of a trope but it's not too predictable. It's fairly light on text and dialogue and a lot of the story is conveyed by floating captions as your character walks past objects in the level and thinks about them. It really could have used that "cinematic cutscenes" stretch goal though. There are many times when your character just exits one playable location and appears in another playable location. Some illustration of the world in between the places, or even some establishing shots, would help the world building a lot. Some things in the game seem like they're going to be a major part of the plot (e.g. the ship's hologram and the goat man) but nothing happens with them. It makes the story feel a little underdeveloped.

I've seen a lot of games on Kickstarter saying they're "inspired by classic titles" just because they've got some retro aesthetic. This is a rare instance of a developer actually meaning it. If you like games like [i]Another World[/i] or [i]Flashback[/i] or [i]BlackThorne[/i] or [i]The Dig[/i] or [i]Indiana Jones and The Fate of Atlantis[/i] then you could like this one. Just give the devs another couple of weeks (from mid-May 2016) to iron out the rest of the bugs. I played the game just after launch and apparently I hit a bug where you can actually skip an entire level. 0:40 to 0:47 in the game trailer is stuff I won't see unless I replay the game.

23117384.review:
An atmospheric, emotional journey, buried in a very tough, occasionally incredibly frustrating game.

I had thought the game would be more like a point & click adventure with occasional action elements, but it's a lot more like a platformer, with adventure game elements. Use of a controller is recommended, although I switched back and forth between controller and keyboard + mouse every now and then.

You will die a lot in this game. It takes inspiration from cinematic platformers like Another World and Flashback, but the movement is a lot less thoughtful, leading to some clunky, often punishing platforming. There is also quite a bit of combat, so slight word of warning for those expecting a quiet exploration game. Most of the time the balance is fine and while the instant deaths are pretty harsh, the sights and sounds you experience push you on. But you will inevitably hit a few extremely frustrating sequences where you will die over and over and eventually it won't feel like your fault anymore.

There's some excellent and surprisingly tough puzzles, something I would have liked to see more of. There's genuine feeling of discovery and accomplishment to be had on solving some of them. The soundtrack and environments are superb, with some wonderful alien architecture to get the imagination racing. I would love to see an adventure game from the team, one that combines the world building and artistic and puzzle design talents of the developer, with slightly less punishing gameplay.

Ultimately it's a very memorable little game and I'm glad I pledged in the kickstarter. Goodness if I didn't curse very, VERY loudly several times during the game though. I imagine many of the frustrations will be evened out in later patches and people will be able to enjoy the journey better.

7/10

Kickstarted this game, so I've got a head start on retail of two days and write this review having finished the game.

If you enjoyed Out of This World (or the original Prince of Persia or Sword Brothers), it has a very similar playstyle to that masterpiece, down to the otherworldliness, the spot on art and music, and the action oriented nature of some of the puzzles (particularly a very tense chase scene versus a more powerful foe).

Some of the puzzles require a little too much backtracking, the controls can be a little stiff (definitely more so than Another World), which definitely lead to frustration in parts... sometimes unclear pixel collision etc, but nothing insurmountable. An awesome freshman effort, I think.

The checkpoints are also somewhat randomly spaced, requiring too much repetition of puzzles you've completed 20 times already... hopefully they can fix some of these issues that only serve to add tedium (not difficulty) in a non-fun way.

Alot of mixing of gaming genres in mini-segments also adds alot to the game (there is a bullet-hell segment, a few side-scrolling lane chases, some arcadey segments).

There aren't enough of these games out there, and this is a worthy entry among them. You can really see the devotion of the devs in crafting something of an homage to Eric Chahi, and I loved their story. 

Give it a go!

23104850.review:
I fell in love with the idea of The Way at first glance, and I am one of the original Kickstarter backers. I am pleased to say that it was money well spent. 

The Way is a sci-fi action-platformer with lots of tricky puzzles, tense moments, and gorgeous pixel art. The art is definitely something that will satisfy pixel-art lovers; it's sumptuous and creepy, weird and glorious, immersive and attractive. It feels like a top-tier 256-colour VGA game from the 90s. Obviously, they were going for a vintage look, but what they achieved here is a work of art, no matter your perspective on retro games.

The first five minutes of the story had me hooked (and successfully pulled me away from Stellaris -- for the moment). They manage to exposit so much information and evoke strong emotions entirely without dialogue. You walk around and little words pop up all over the place, telling you what things are. Some items imply a great deal of emotional depth in the story -- stuff like "bed without her" and "cheap take-out food." The narrative design is really out of the box so far. 

The story is certainly my favourite element, but other things deserve mention. The soundtrack is a great cyberpunk/ambient mix that lends a lot of gravity to each moment. The puzzles are tricky and require some thinking and a little bit of making notes, but none have been so hard as to force me to look for online hints. The enemies are deadly -- most kill with one hit -- but the checkpoints are frequent and the reload time is almost instantaneous. A quick reload time is critical when death is so easy (I'm looking at you, Hyper Light Drifter). 

If you loved games like Another World and Flashback, give this a try. Because it's best in class where that genre is concerned.

23104679.review: Great old school style pixel adventure. Bring a notebook for clues, becuase it's that type of party. As other reviewers stated: if you love Another World, you'll be at home here.

23104592.review:
This is ostensibly a platformer/shooting game, but it plays more like an adventure game. It is heavily inspired by Another World/Out of this World, Flashback, and Heart of Darkness, platformers from the past whose charm for me lies in using atmosphere instead of plot to tell a story, and in creating very unique organic scenes that don't feel like a bunch of mechanics thrown together. This is a blessing and a curse, both in these older games and in The Way. They have emulated the style so well that even some of the clunky controls have been carried over.

The game is divided up into sequences, those sequences existing in a few separate scenes. Each sequence has it's own unique twist. What you learn in one sequence may or may not help you in the next. This keeps you learning new things and keeps you on your toes, but the downside is you never feel like you are mastering a system. Some of the controls like aiming and jumping, which you would expect to be very responsive and feel freeing, can be restrictive and clunky here. But for the most part, the game is designed around these clunky systems, and fall in line with a main character who is not an action hero. Expect a lot of memorization of the exact timing and actions to take to get through the next challenge. There is also some pretty fun puzzle solving.

The story is light, but provides enough motivation to keep working through the game, even during some of the more frustrating sections. You will be cursing as you go back to the last, just barely too far away, checkpoint, but then you will push ahead for more. 

The graphics are old-school but gorgeous, especially on a large screen. There is a lot of detail and animation in the environments. The music and sound design work with the graphics to provide the appropriate otherworldly mood - a mood which I haven't quite felt since Flashback. For me, Another World is still king of this subgenre, but The Way largely succeeds in creating a similar and engaging adventure.

23103090.review:
I have to say Another World (aka Out of This World) is probably on of my favourite games growing up. So when I first saw [b]The Way[/b] I was filled with that warm glow of nostalgia - a old school puzzle platformer in the style of the Eric Chahi classics. Beautiful alien worlds brought to life with a simple, 2D art style with puzzles designed to challenge you and where everything in the world is liable to kill you.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1R6qSsLJzv0

Yes, the story is a little hokey. You whisk away the frozen remains of you dead wife to an alien world in search of the Temple of Life and a "way" to bring her back to the land of the living. It's pretty cheesey but it works and I was hooked enough to want to find out how it all panned out. 

That said, from what I've played so far [b]The Way[/b] may mirror those old platformers a little [i]too[/i] well. The simplest of things can kill you and the infrequent checkpoints will see you repeating sections over and over again, which can lead to more than a little frustration. Coupled with the somewhat inperfect controls you may be raging after Commader Tom fails to make that ledge grab and falls to his death for the sixth or seventh time.

Regardless this really is a love letter to games like Another World and Flashback. And if enjoyed them then this is defintiely worth checking out.

Highly recommended.

23102878.review: An amazing game akin to Another World and Oddworld. Beautiful art, excellent music and an emotional story make this puzzle adventure game an unforgettable experience.

23102627.review:
Großartiges Spiel, eine Mischung aus  "The Dig" und "Another World". Man wird sich in vielen Szenen an eines der beiden Spiele erinnert fühlen. Das Spiel selbst kommt mit dezenten Dialogen aus und arbeitet viel mit kurzen Eindrucken. Die Stärke des Spiels sind die wunderbar atmosphärischen Orte und die unglaublich abwechslungsreichen und wirklich schweren Puzzle. Hier gibt es auch kaum ein widerholendes Muster. Hat man sich gerade an eine Art von Rätzeln gewöhnt, wird man mit ganz neuen konfrontiert. 
Die Story kann auch sehr gut überzeugen und macht einen andauernd neugierig darauf, wie es denn nun weiter geht.

Sobald man ein Rätzel gelöst hat, ist man wirklcih stolz auf sich, weil diese teilweise wirklich kniffelig sind. Und man wird jedes mal mit neuen schönen Szenen und dem weiteren Verlauf der Story belohnt. 

Hierbei ist das Spiel gut ausgewogen zwischen Geschicklichkeitsrätzeln, Rätzeln zum nachdenken oder auch Rätzel wo man sich etwas aufzeichnen muss.

23102588.review:
A game that sets out to rebottle some of the lightning of Eric Chahi's groundbreaking Another World has some pretty big shoes to fill. There have been attempts to craft another game in its vein, ranging from the attempted direct sequel Heart of the Alien to the famous and well-regarded spiritual successor Flashback, and while many of these games are quite fun, I'd be hard-pressed to call any of them, even Flashback, equals to Chahi's masterpiece. Another World was simply without rival. I just completed it, and I can say with confidence that this game is indeed Another World's most worthy successor to date. This is the game I've been waiting for, and were I Eric Chahi, I'd be quite flattered by it.

Let me begin with a single caveat: this game demands a modern gamepad with dual analog sticks. Certain scenes are demanding enough with one, but nigh-unbeatable with keys, and I haven't found a good way to control some of the later powers acquired in the game without analog sticks. One particular chase sequence, affectionately called "The Nope" by some players...well, let's just say that I *did* complete it before switching to gamepad, and I consider that to be one of my greatest feats of gamer-fu to date. Save yourself the trouble: grab a modern gamepad to play this one.

Even during its "easy" first level, the game's no slouch, and expects you to think on your toes, to put together a large collection of data and refer to it while remaining unseen by various mechanical "eyes," and to solve some downright puzzly problems. This is a new element that The Way brings to the table, something that neither Another World nor Flashback explored much -- both the stealth elements and the puzzle elements add a forced "mental gear change," and I found myself enjoying the regular flips between twitch action and strategic planning quite enjoyable. This would have been easy to get wrong, but The Way, so far, has done a splendid job marrying its alma mater to entirely new territory. The puzzle difficulty is quite demanding, but has never yet felt unfair or even unreasonably taxing. (MABEC will surely earn some choice curse words from some players, but in this reviewer's humble opinion, it was merely demanding, not unreasonable.)

The visual design is quite beautiful. It's not quite as smooth as Another World's flat plane of polygons-under-glass, but I don't find that I mind the shift to painted pixels at all -- they're beautiful, and used to great visual effect, with a great deal of information conveyed in, at times, one or two pixels. The levels scroll, unlike Another World and Flashback, but I don't find that I mind this at all; it helps the player map the space, and the relationships between rooms and areas. The lighting effects are particularly beautiful, and quite subtle to boot. I might have liked to see our protagonist have additional Broderbund-like fluidity of movement, but that might have come about at cost to timing and responsiveness. The Way's controls are very responsive, and when the protagonist missed a jump, I never felt the game was to blame, only my own clumsiness. That impressed me -- the balance of "forgiving" and "demanding" felt just right for a first level, and reminded me a lot of Another World's. This is not an easy game, but it's self-aware, knows this, and difficulty ramps nicely over time.

The autosave feature bookmarks the game at certain milestones on your path, and additionally, keeps a journal of your deliverables, much like a modern RPG, so you can easily check to see what's left undone to proceed. I had worried this might diminish my sense of accomplishment figuring out what the game asked of me, but the game remains minimal in its "instructions" there. The "task list" is just helpful enough, and easy to disregard completely if you prefer to play by memory alone.

I've heard of people beating the game after nine hours of play, but I suspect that's quite aggressive and not typical for a first-time player. It took me nearly twenty-five hours to complete, and that amount of playtime for the price is excellent, much greater than Flashback's, let alone Another World's. 

Everything I wanted to see from Another World was there -- the breakneck chases, the deadly and unforgiving alien world, the myriad causes of the protagonist's sudden deaths, the pixel-perfect frustrating jumps and dodges, the haunting, atmospheric yet minimal soundtrack. But so many things I didn't expect were in there, too -- stealth-action elements, Machinarium/The Dig-style heavier puzzles, and a richness and broadness to the world that really made it worth the two-years-past-deadline wait. This game was clearly its creators' prize jewel, and the attention to its faceting and polishing cannot be missed. In that one respect, it's more like Another World than even Flashback -- it is very recognizably a personal magnum opus, an expression of love for a genre rarely visited these days. In that one respect above all others, this is well and truly the game Another World fans have been waiting to play for years.

It's not just "Another World, one more time." It's the modern child of Another World, and it is both aware of its lineage and responsibility to its fans, but also determined to be remembered as more than simply a "cover band" of its alma mater's greatest hits. This is, put simply, everything I wanted The Way to be, and some things I didn't yet realize I wanted from it.

Brilliant. This is the Another World spiritual successor we've been waiting for.

[EDIT: Minor updates acknowledging that I've since completed the game.)
